dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB WILEY'S BATHROOM, MORNING
dialogues.text: BOB WILEY, thirties, anxious, begins brushing his teeth.  Suddenly, in trying to brush a back molar, Bob looses con of the toothbrush and swallows half of it whole. Choking, gasping, he tries to pull the toothbrush out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN and TILT up from a woman walking her dog on the stree of Manhattan to a third floor apartment window. There is struggling frantically with the toothbrush.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB WILEY'S BATHROOM, MORNING
dialogues.text: Bob is losing the battle, and in three excruciating swall like a mouse going down the throat of a snake, the toothb disappears down his throat. Bob pounds his chest, swallow as he does. Then, delicately, he belches. He takes a deep breath, relaxes somewhat, and opens the medicine cabinet. There sit ten packaged toothbrushes. Bob opens one. AS WE... END CREDITS...

dialogues.speaker: AUTUMN
dialogues.text: Pricey BMW's, MERCEDES, etc. sport license plates which r FREUD JUNGNRICH HEADDOC PERCA' DAN' etc. Three pre-teens  ride by on bikes and shove the trunks of the cars. Car al sound off like birds. We PAN WITH THE KIDS then PAST THEM out to sea to see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four psychiatrists and three spouses are pleasure boating Here all is quiet except the wind and the sound of the bi (or is it the car alarms?). Shrinks and their wives sit a an intense doctor in his forties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had the same nightmare three  nights running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, David, we're on a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving my office for summer  vacation, when suddenly my patients  rush up looking insane.

dialogues.speaker: MOTION
dialogues.text: Dr. Feinberg exits the building with his suitcase. To his horror an angry horde of men and women, looking like a  sadistic lynch mob, swarm him and attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Don't leave us!" they scream. Then  they beat me and bite me and kill  me...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Feinberg runs to get away he is dragged down then over by his angry patients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the worst nightmare I've had  since residency. Night after night...  it's terrifying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least your nightmare is only a  dream. What about what happened to  Leo Marvin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Leo Marvin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never heard of the famous Dr.  Marvin?

dialogues.speaker: A VACANT LOT ON SHORE
dialogues.text: There is a dock, an overgrown slab, and a chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That used to be his vacation house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab a strong drink and some  Dramamine. I'll tell you a story  that will send you into Rorschach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Leo Marvin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I really can't tell you about  Leo Marvin unless I first tell you  about Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Bob?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE STREETS OF MANHATTAN, UPPER WEST SIDE, DAY
dialogues.text: The SOUND of BIRDS segues to car alarms. We're on the str of New York, CRANING and ZOOMING like a bird up and into sweltering apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Wiley sits on his bed in boxer shorts. On his night s are cardboard plaques: one lists the warning signs of  diabetes, another lists cancer's seven warning signals.  Stacked by the bed are psychology books and a few bottles prescription pills. In front of Bob is a vaporizer. Bob h his cheeks and twists them in small circles in front of t steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a mantra-like chant) I feel good. I feel great. I feel  wonderful! I feel good. I feel great.  I feel wonderful! I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who's Leo Marvin? I know I've  heard the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he the guy who specialized in  necrophiliacs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! (sighs) If you must.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A PSYCHIATRIST'S OFFICE, DAY
dialogues.text: The striking thing about DR. LEO MARVIN's office is order and neatness. As Marvin talks on the phone, he unconsciou adjusts the already meticulously placed gewgaws on his de Marvin is mid-forties, authoritative, stiff, perfectly  manicured. Adorning the office are diplomas, personal  mementos, primitive masks, Mondrian-like paintings, his f medical school grades, a bust of Freud, and diplomas. On desk is a book titled Baby Steps TM with Marvin's picture it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I want to publicize the  book, Hugo and it's a wonderful  opportunity, but its my vacation.  The Today Show went to Dr. Ruth's  vacation house, why can't CBS Morning  come to Lake Winnipesaukee?... Would  you work on it?... Thank you Hugo. I  appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin, there's a Dr. Carswell  Fensterwald calling. He says you  went to school together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wracking his memory) Fensterwald. Carswell Fensterwald.  It sounds familiar but... They sure  come out of the woodwork when you  get famous, Clair. Put him through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carswell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carswell Fensterwald looks unstable. As he talks on his p he is boxing up his office. Prominent on his desk is a co of Marvin's book. The conversation INTERCUTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time no see, huh? You have a  big book out. Things are clicking,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way I planned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Leo, I'm closing my practice.  Most of my patients are on the West  Side but I have one case I'd like to  refer you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carswell, thanks but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, you're incredibly busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swamped. I've raised my rate. I might  even cut my sessions to forty  minutes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, I know you don't like flattery  but if anybody I know is going to  win a Nobel Prize, it's you. You  gotta be thinking about your next  book so I know you'll find this case  particularly interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of case is it, Carswell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin paces. He adjusts a diploma down, then up, then do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, Leo, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carswell, if this is a dysfunctional --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, nothing like that. He keeps  his appointments. Pays on time. See  him once. If he's not the most complex  and -- persistent -- case you've  ever seen, drop him. His name's Bob  Wiley. He needs someone brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll work him in for an  interview. Say, Carswell, how come  you're quitting the business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a dying breed, Leo. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fensterwald hangs up. He lets out a silent jubilant howl gleeful laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel good. I feel great. I feel  wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Marvin slowly hangs up his speaker phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carswell Fensterwald...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again he racks his brains. He presses his intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire, if I get a call from a Bob  Wiley, schedule him for a short  interview after vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's already called, Dr. Marvin.  Twice. He's coming in this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one kind of persistence.  Carswell Fensterwald...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin gives up. He picks up a copy of his book. He compa his jacket photo with his reflection in the handle of his letter opener.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ABOARD THE CRIS CRAFT BOAT, DAY
dialogues.text: The shrinks are still listening to Doctor 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Marvin. Now I remember. An  incredible asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had that stupid best seller, what  was the name of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching grass grow was more exciting  than Leo Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm trying to tell you  lummoxes: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S APARTMENT, DAY
dialogues.text: Bob is sitting by the steam repeating his mantra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel good. I feel great. I feel  wonderful! I feel good, I feel great!  I feel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob picks up the phone and frantically pushes buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Claire, Bob again. Are you  sure Dr. Marvin doesn't have an  earlier cancellation?... Sorry. See  you at two, sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob hangs up, finds a blood pressure gauge and takes his  blood pressure. That done, he stands, paces, then stops a sprinkles food into a gold fish bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIL the GOLDFISH nibbles the food. Bob sits on his bed, t a deep breath, then dials the phone. As he waits for an  answer, he flips through his "organizer" which is crammed with notes and papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Bob Wiley calling... (checks in his notebook) Mrs. Patricia Lions please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob waits a beat, still looking through the notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lions, I'm Bob Wiley. I represent  the Manhattan Dental Hygiene  Association. I can offer you a forty  percent discount on our toothpicks  plus a very attractive selection of  toothpick holders if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Wiley --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, this is an elementary school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elementary school? (checks his notebook) I thought you were Overton Cafeteria?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're a school and we don't need  toothpicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. A young tooth is a  terrible thing to waste. I should  know. When I was that age nobody  gave a hoot about my teeth and now  they're terrible! Have you checked  out flavored floss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flavored floss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do is dream pink  gums, Patsy, and we can make them  happen. Give me your address and  I'll send you our flossing catalogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bob begins to write on his notebook, he flashes a "V" victory at Gil.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S APARTMENT, LATER
dialogues.text: Bob is now dressed to go out. A clock reads 1:45pm. Bob i pacing at the door. He stops, glances at the clock, faces the door, opens it, closes it. He paces, opens the door,  takes some deep breaths, twists his cheeks, then like a m jumping into cold water, bolts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob exits his apartment, uses a Kleenex to close the door then heads down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DOORWAY TO BOB'S APARTMENT BUILDING, DAY
dialogues.text: Sweat pouring off his brow, Bob stands in sunglasses in t entrance-way to his apartment. A bus squeals up to the cu belches smoke, then moves on. A garbage can is kicked ove Bob starts to take a step when suddenly he gets dizzy. He steps back and hyperventilates. Bob puts on a dust mask,  steps bravely onto the sidewalk, and walks, eyes fixed  forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel good, I feel great, I feel  wonderful. (repeats)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man passes Bob, eyes fixed forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch, dirty bastard, I'll  get you! (repeats)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob walks through the city like a zombie, eyes fixed forw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passers-by shuffle to and fro. Bob, still in sunglasses a dust mask, enters. He walks in a straight line to the bui directory. He finds: "Dr. Leo Marvin, A Psychiatric Corporation, suite 4616."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This startles Bob but he recovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to see Dr. Leo Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second elevator. 46th floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: THE ELEVATORS
dialogues.text: Bob removes a Kleenex from a pack in his pocket, uses it push the elevator button, then paces nervously. The eleva arrives and the door opens. The elevator is filling up wi passengers. Bob doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a descending steel staircase and stairwell door ma "Floor 40". We hear footsteps -- rhythmic and determined getting closer and closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel good, I feel great, I feel  wonderful. (repeats over and  over)

dialogues.speaker: INT. DR. MARVIN'S RECEPTION ROOM, DAY
dialogues.text: Clair sits behind her desk reading a book. Bob enters, re faced and out of breath, taking his pulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... I'm... Bob...

dialogues.speaker: INT. DR. MARVIN'S OFFICE, DAY
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin is at his desk. Claire shows in Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin. Bob Wiley. Thank you for  working me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire exits. Bob looks around then notices a framed phot on Marvin's shelf. Using his Kleenex, Bob picks it up. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family? (Marvin nods) Wait, let me guess. I'm good at this.  Harriet, Kenny, Gretchen, Rita. Wait  wait, I know I'm close. Susan, Steven,  Andrea, Rita. Wait --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emotionless) My wife, Fay. My son, Sigmund. My  daughter, Anna. My sister, Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily... I was close! What a wonderful  family!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob puts the photo back on the shelf. Marvin adjusts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I call you Dr. Marvin or Leo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whichever you prefer. Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stares at the chair. There is a box of Kleenexes on t arm. Bob reaches in his pocket, takes out a Kleenex, and  uses it to move the box of Kleenexes to the table. He the sits. Marvin walks to Bob and holds out a trash can. Bob  drops in the used Kleenex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin puts the trash can next to Bob's chair then sits. stares at Bob. He's waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm on, huh? (pause) Well, the simplest way to put it is,  I have problems. I worry er, about  diseases. I have trouble with  toothbrushes. And I, er, I have  problems moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as I'm in my apartment, I'm  okay. I have a phone job -- selling  dental supplies -- and that's fine.  But when I have to go out, I get...,  weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get dizzy spells. Nausea. Cold  sweats. Hot sweats. Fever blisters.  Difficulty swallowing. Difficulty  breathing. Blurred vision. Involuntary  trembling. Dead hands. Weak ankles.  Twitching. Fainting spells. Numb  lips. (pause) Do you think that's normal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Bob removes an air sickness bag from his pocket. opens it and pauses a long time as though he were about t vomit into it. He doesn't. He puts the air sickness bag a Marvin leans in. Bob does too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do go out, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. What if I break my neck and  become paraplegic? What if my heart  stops beating, or I can't find a  bathroom and my bladder explodes?  You ever heard of Tourette's Syndrome.  You know, where you involuntarily  shout profanity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exceptionally rare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a neighbor who got it. Yells  "oh shit!" in church. "Douche bag!"  at customers at his job. Pretty funny,  actually, unless you're the one with  the disease. Then it's sad. (pause) OH SHIT EATING SON OF A BITCH! Just  kidding. (pause) TWAT LOVING DOUCHE BAG!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, if I fake it, I know I  don't have it. Like, when I think my  heart is gonna stop. I fake it so I  know it's not happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob fakes a heart seizure -- very convincingly -- and fal to the floor. After a moment, he sits back in the chair a if nothing had happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can't make it happen, I know  it's not happening. I know it's all  in my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stands and walks towards Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from me with that knife! (laughs) See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin uprights the trashcan and walks back to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divorced, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is divided into two types  of people: those who like Neil Diamond  and those who don't. My ex-wife loves  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin, do you think you can  help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause. Marvin leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a saying, Bob, that the best  psychiatrist in the world is right  inside of you. I can help you,  provided you're willing to help  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, I'll do anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stands and moves to the bookcase behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a ground breaking book that  just came out, Bob. Not everything  in it applies to you but when you  see the title, I think you'll see  that it can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are twenty copies of Marvin's book on the shelf beh Marvin. Marvin holds one up. Bob sees the cover. We see t picture of Marvin on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby Steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means setting small, reasonable  goals for yourself. One day at a  time, one tiny step at a time -- do- able, accomplishable goals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you leave this office, don't  think about everything you have to  do to get out of the building, just  deal with getting out of the room.  When you reach the hall, just deal  with the hall. And so forth. Baby  steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks at Marvin then stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step... through the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob takes small deliberate steps to the door. He opens it and steps into the reception area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step... out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the office closes. There is a long pause. Bob opens the door and pops back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It works!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I have to do is take one small  step at a time and I can do anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. But don't expect everything  all at once. Even a baby occasionally  falls and hits his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob walks around the room as though he were inhabiting ea small space with his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step around the office. Baby  step around the office! (to Marvin's family  photo) Fay, Sigmund, Anna, Lily: Hi fam!  He's a genius!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin hands Bob the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will give you plenty to digest  while I'm on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly my secretary told you. As  of this afternoon, I'm on vacation  with my family until Labor Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a whole month! What if I need  you? What if I need to talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Harmon, my associate will be  happy to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Bob Harmon's card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have years ahead of us, Bob. A  month will seem like a baby second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin shows Bob the door. Bob, doing his baby steps, loo lost and confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I call you in the Hamptons if I  need you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Harmon is quite skilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob shuffles to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear Maine is great this time of  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns over his book and shows Bob his picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be with you the whole month.  Try your baby steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see... Baby step through the  office. Baby step out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's perfect. Keep going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby steps to the hall. Baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin closes the door and starts back to his desk.  Momentarily, Bob sticks his head back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Catskills, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Baby steps. Baby steps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob exits, closing the door. Marvin starts to pick up Bob trash can when Bob sticks his head in again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You flying or driving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob. (firmly re-assuring) I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks at Marvin then starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby steps, he'll be back. Baby steps,  he'll be back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob closes the door behind him. From his desk Marvin take plastic trash bag and dumps the contents of Bob's trash c into it. He picks up a small tape recorder and presses  "record".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: July 31, Bob Wiley, introductory  interview. Multi-phobic personality  characterized by an extreme need for  family connections. Bill $150 for  the session and $29.95 for the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks the tape recorder off. There is a knock on the  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire puts her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your publicist. He says CBS  will come to Winnipesaukee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin strides triumphantly to the phone and lifts it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew they'd come to me! Hugo, not  to change the subject but has a  psychiatrist ever won the Nobel Prize?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob paces in front of the elevators, reading the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step to the elevator. Baby step  to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator, full of passengers, opens. Bob, steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step to the elevator. Baby step  to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors close and it starts down. Bob screams.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE NEW YORK MARINE AIR TERMINAL, DAY
dialogues.text: Marvin and family (who we recognize from the pictures in  Marvin's office) exit a cab with their luggage and head i the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry hurry hurry. Hurry hurry hurry.  Hurry hurry hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass a HOMELESS MAN with a hand out. Marvin's wife F stops and roots in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey there isn't time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay gives the man some money then enters the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're only encouraging them, Fay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marvin family hurries through the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry hurry hurry. Hurry hurry  hurry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin's 16 year old daughter ANNA and 12 year old son SI rush with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, would you cut it out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family finds their gate and gets in line to board. Th are ten people ahead of them and the plane isn't boarding yet. All haste stops as they drop their luggage to the fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I told you there was no rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nice looking BOY gets in line behind them and checks ou Anna. She sees him and flips her hair. Siggy, dressed in black, plays a video game on his watch. It beeps and blur FAY lovingly plucks a piece of lint off Marvin's jacket.  Siggy looks up and plucks off another piece of lint. Marv takes out an electronic organizer. He pushes buttons and beeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, how does this sound? Tomorrow:  we'll go shopping and clean up the  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooo, sounds great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday we'll re-arrange the  furniture and spruce up the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More, I gotta have more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin clears his throat and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sing song) The interview with Maria Shriver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swelling with pride) I'm having some art brought up from  the city. The cottage should look  spectacular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay kisses Marvin on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure whatever you do will look  wonderful, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin beams then goes back to his organizer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the interview we'll take a  celebration sail around lake, then  Friday -- my birthday -- we'll have  wonderful meal at Digby's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay straightens Siggy's shirt tail. Momentarily, Siggy's  watch lets out a staccato series of beeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy, are you going to spend all  summer driving us crazy with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not driving me crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy continues his game. Fay touches Marvin on the hand say, let it pass. Anna continues to flirt with the boy in line. Marvin pushes a couple of buttons on his organizer it lets out three rapid beeps. Siggy smiles triumphantly Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna do that all summer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin ignores this and puts the organizer away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, dad, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna you're masking hostility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin reaches in his briefcase and removes two HAND PUPP One has the silk screened face of Anna, the other of Leo. Anna sees this and is incredibly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intense) Daddy, put those away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line moves. Anna hurries into the ramp way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna. Examine your behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin and the family disappear into the ramp way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Leo Marvin, pick up the white  courtesy phone. Dr. Leo Marvin, please  answer the white courtesy phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long list of airline phone numbers with all but the las one crossed out. PULL BACK TO FIND: BOB standing at a pay phone, receiver to his ear. He has  Kleenexes protecting his hand, his ear and his mouth. Out the window is a hot dog stand. The vendor is serving up j hot dogs and Bob watches longingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Bob. No one's answering  the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob hangs up and crumples the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still looking at the hot dogs, Bob shuffles out of the ph booth. He tosses his crumpled list at a trash can and mis Even though there is litter on the street all around the  trash can, Bob (using a Kleenex) picks up his list and pu it in the trash. He walks to the hot dog stand and watche He wants a hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you, bub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a hot dog, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure would...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vendor buns a hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mustard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sauerkraut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vendor holds out the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't. I really want to but I  can't. It's bird intestine and beef  brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks at the dog with a mixture of desire and revulsi He pulls out an air sickness bag, holds it ready, then pu it back. The vendor retracts the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit the road, bub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob moves on.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A SUNNY NEW YORK FLAT, DAY
dialogues.text: Bob, out of breath, knocks on the door. HELENE WILEY, a l middle aged woman draped in diaphanous scarves, opens the door. She carries a palette knife and palette of paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, you didn't walk up again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found this great psychiatrist who  abandoned me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helene turns and walks away. Bob follows her in. The next scene is played with Helene walking away and Bob followin They move through her apartment, dotted with finished and half-finished paintings on big canvases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you come here for money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, that's a terrible thing to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like my latest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops in front of a BIG CANVAS covered with knives,  spoons, forks, paint, and twenty dollar bills. Bob touche one of the twenties. It comes off in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lovely mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helene takes the twenty and puts it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, I'm sorry! All I wanted to do  was talk. I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches out and embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my poor baby. How did you get so  screwed up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the only thing I care about.  Always will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand there hugging for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here for you, Bob. Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him and lovingly straightens his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, sweetie. I need to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stands on the corner looking like a lost soul. He wat as the world passes by. The light changes. Looking both w constantly, Bob crosses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step across the street. Baby  step across the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "perfect little family" walks past him. A five year old girl and a three year old boy skip by, hand in hand. They wave at Bob. He waves back, sadly, then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affectless) I feel good, I feel great, I feel  wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A BABY DECORATED APARTMENT, DAY
dialogues.text: "Crackling Rose" by Neil Diamond plays on the stereo. BEC a perky woman, pregnant, about Bob's age, answers the doo Bob stands in the hallway. She's a little surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa!... You're really getting big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob gently puts his hand on Becky's belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a bruiser. Hi little Bobby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Bob, he's not little Bobby. Feel the  heartbeat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob puts his ear to Becky's belly and listens. Suddenly, hugs Becky's tummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Becky, let's get married again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away) Bob. You know I'm married to some  one else now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding on) But I want a baby. A family! I want  to burp him and change him and...  love him! (pause -- lets go) Why couldn't it have been with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, honey, we've been over this.  You as a father? Think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob sinks. Becky looks at him sympathetically. There is s a warm spot in her heart for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I actually have considered  naming him "Bob".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But it's still going to be  "Neil".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognizing Neil  Diamond on the stereo) Right.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S APARTMENT, LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Bob sits alone watching Ozzie and Harriet. Ozzie is talki to Ricky, David, and Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a family. We'll always be a  family. I don't care what they say  about you at school, we've got each  other and don't you ever forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family hugs. The TV audience applauds. Bob picks up t phone and dials. SPLIT SCREEN with MID-MANHATTAN EXCHANGE one room, two operator answering service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-Manhattan Exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Bob Wiley. I'm a patient of  Dr. Marvin's. I need to talk to him.  Urgently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Mr. Wiley --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Bob, but Dr. Marvin is out of  town and Dr. Harmon is taking his  calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want Harmon, I need Marvin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob paces then assumes a false calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, there seems to be some  confusion. You see, Dr. Marvin, uh,  Leo, wanted me to call him but I  lost his number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob. I can't give out that number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you could call him and ask him  to call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's awfully late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is silent. Bessie is uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay on the line, Bob. What's your  number in case we get disconnected?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MARVIN'S VACATION HOUSE PORCH, LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: We recognize this as the same lake the doctors were saili in the opening scene: gorgeous greenery, the shore lined  with quaint but expensive summer homes. Where the doctors the boat saw an empty slab, stands the Marvin summer hous a clapboard structure complete with a private dock, old w motorized rowboat, and diving board. Marvin is relaxing in a chair. Fay is in the background  putting out flowers. Marvin takes a deep breath, sighs  peacefully then picks up a book: Freud's Understanding Dr and opens it. The phone rings. Marvin frowns, then answer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin, this is Bessie at your  exchange. I'm sorry to disturb you  but I have a Bob Wiley on the line  who says you'll want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know better than this, Bessie.  Dr. Harmon is covering for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him that, Doctor, but he  insists on talking to you. He says  it's an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin frowns then takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put him through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO DOUBLE SPLIT-SCREEN
dialogues.text: Bob's frantic pacing contrasts with Marvin's calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, I thought I made it clear to  you that I'm on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but I'm a mess. Worse than  usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, if this is an emergency, go to  the emergency room. If not, call Dr.  Harmon and I'm sure he can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd feel better if I just knew where  you were. It's Martha's Vineyard  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't we just talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my office, after Labor Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire Island?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin hangs up. SINGLE SCREEN. Bob hangs up too. He stan and thinks then dials again. SPLIT SCREEN WITH MID-MANHAT EXCHANGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Bob. Leo and I got cut  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Bob, but Dr. Marvin just  called and instructed me not to put  you through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stands thinking.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A MANHATTAN PAY PHONE BOOTH, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A mid-twenties PROSTITUTE, overly made up, is on the phon SPLIT SCREEN again with MID-MANHATTAN EXCHANGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-Manhattan exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Lily Marvin, Dr. Leo  Marvin's sister. I have to talk to  my brother right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical) I'm not allowed to give out that  number. Don't you have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PULL BACK REVEALS BOB standing beside the prostitute,  wearing his face mask, waiting anxiously. Bob whispers in the prostitute's ear. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went on vacation and forgot to  give it to me. Look, honey, it's  urgent. I'm at: 790-8864.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reads the number off the pay phone. Bessie reacts to fact that it's a different number from Bob's. She shakes head and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay on the line, Miss Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prostitute hands the phone to Bob. He sprays the phon with disinfectant then hands her some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. You were fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prostitute shakes her head and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MARVIN'S VACATION HOUSE DINING ROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The moonlit lake is in the far background. In the near  background the Marvin family sits eating dinner. Marvin  holding the telephone, looking concerned, walks off by  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPLIT SCREEN WITH Bob, standing at his pay phone. He crin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin, please don't be angry.  It's Bob. I know I shouldn't call  this way but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, listen to me. The doctor-patient  relationship is based on trust. When  you call me against my wishes or  pretend to be my sister, I can't  trust you any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Dr. Harmon, or go to the  emergency room, but don't call me  here again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin hangs up. BACK TO SINGLE SCREEN. Bob stands in the phone booth, banging his hand on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that wasn't smart! Oh that wasn't  smart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out of the booth shaking his head. He exits scre left. Momentarily he crosses back through screen, mutteri to himself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MID-MANHATTAN EXCHANGE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bessie sits at her switchboard, reading a regency romance The operator, GWEN, is doing her nails. There is a knock the door. The operators look at each other, go to the doo but don't open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Roberts. Homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some questions about a Bob  Wiley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gwen) That was that sicko who kept calling  Dr. Marvin. (loud) What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door. Detective Roberts is Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suicide. We think. Forty stories.  Free fall. Splat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The operators gasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now our records show that Bob made  several calls to this number just  before he died. Did either of you  know Bob personally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob called here trying to reach his  psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's interesting. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put him through once. After that,  Dr. Marvin didn't want to talk to  him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh HUH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Dr. Marvin couldn't  have had anything to do with Bob's  death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin's on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of state. Lake Winnipesaukee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michigan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Hampshire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not supposed to give out the  number but I can call him and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. I'm sure we can find  him if we need him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob writes down the information as he walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I feel terrible. What if I was  the last person he talked to before  he died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I frankly wouldn't let it bother me.  This guy had "sky diver" written all  over him if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob almost throws up then puts the air sickness bag away  again. He takes a deep breath, smiles to himself, then ex

dialogues.speaker: INT. MARVIN'S SUMMER HOUSE BEDROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Marvin and Fay are asleep in bed. The phone rings. Fay tu on the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd better not be who I think it  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin answers the phone. Fay listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... What?... That's okay. Thanks  for calling, Bessie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin hangs up. He sits, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my service. That patient --  the one who called earlier --  committed suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Leo, how horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay rubs Marvin's neck. There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well. Let's not let it ruin our  vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns out the light and lies down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A BUS STATION, MORNING
dialogues.text: Bob wears bermuda shorts and baseball cap. In one hand, l a security blanket, he clutches a paper bag spilling over with clothes, bottles of pills, and Baby Steps. In the ot hand he clutches a baggie holding Gil. Eyes fixed ahead, stares at: A BUS looming large like a growling grumbling snorting  monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last bus to Winnipesaukee,  Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many tunnels does it pass through  again? How many bridges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you keep your eyes closed, you  won't see any of them. You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby steps, board the bus. Baby steps,  board the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks at the bus again. He tips his bottle of pills a swallows. He takes a small baby step towards the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you could do it today,  Bob. We have a baby schedule to keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step, board today. Baby step,  board today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob inches into the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus driver sits ready to go. Bob walks like a cripple d the aisle to an empty seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step, down the aisle. Baby step,  down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passengers, a scurvy bunch, wait impatiently. Bob fin takes a seat next to an old man and smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man scowls and looks forward. The bus driver clos the door and the bus moves forward with a jolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!! (turns to the old man) Would you knock me out, please?! Hit  me in the face, whatever you have to  do, just knock me out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man moves away. Bob downs more pills.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE HOLLAND TUNNEL, DAY
dialogues.text: The bus speeds through. We HEAR a long, loud SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN PORCH, DAY
dialogues.text: Marvin lies down in the hammock and picks up his book. Fa enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, let's go to the store.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE OPEN COUNTRYSIDE, DAY
dialogues.text: The Greyhound bus stops. Bob gets out and runs into a fie He apparently vomits, then runs back to the bus.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LAKE WINNIPESAUKEE GENERAL STORE, DAY
dialogues.text: The Marvin family strolls through this old fashioned Gene Store, loading food and supplies into a shopping cart. Th all in shorts and looking resorty except for Siggy who is his usual all-black garb. Through the windows, outside, w can see the quaint little town of Winnipesaukee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo said to expect eleven. Are you  sure we have enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could feed the entire network,  honey. Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna joins them and tosses in some cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Anna) By the way, did you call Ted Fein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? He's a salami with eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know a boy is cute?  Are you coming out of the closet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna. Be nice. (she fixes Anna's  collar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) She's just testing us, Fay. But don't  get psycho-sexual with me young lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? When you want me to call some  guy cause his father's your publicist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, dad. Don't be a psychosexual  pimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy, don't talk that way to your  father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're both testing us, Fay. Don't  buy into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, mom. It's not meant for you,  it's meant for dad. (at his father) Testing. 1, 2, 3. Testing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE BUS STOP ACROSS FROM THE GENERAL STORE, DAY
dialogues.text: A GREYHOUND BUS pulls to the bus stop. Passengers hurry o anxiously glancing behind them. Finally Bob, covered in s exits. Holding his bag and fish, squinting to adjust to t sun, he stands in a daze as the bus pulls away. After a l pause, Bob calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin! Dr. Leo Marvin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob waits. Passers-by turn and stare. There is no Leo Mar in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin! Dr. Leo Marvin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marvin family exits carrying groceries. They stop at family station wagon and begin loading up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Leo Marvin. Dr. Leo Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, is somebody calling you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Marvin. Dr. Leo Marvin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns and sees Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god... I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BUS STOP
dialogues.text: Bob looks in all directions. Suddenly he sees Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin. It's you!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob walks toward the Marvins.

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN
dialogues.text: stands dumfounded. He watches Bob walking towards them. H tries to stay calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know that man, Leo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin! It's me, Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intense) Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay is surprised to see Leo so forceful. She hustles the  kids into the station wagon. Bob hurries up, out of breat In one hand he holds his bag. In the other he holds Gil i baggie. Marvin closes the station wagon door and stands  outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! This is Gil. It must be fate  that I found you so quickly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stops and stands, a little out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a bad time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? I thought  you were..., dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, they told you? I fibbed a  little but... Don't be mad. (spotting the family  in the car) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sweet beatific smile appears on Bob's face. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin leads Bob away from the car, across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stops and faces Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you know, Bob, that your  behavior is entirely inappropriate.  We talked about trust. We talked  about my needs. I want you to get on  a bus and go back to New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then can't we just talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see patients on vacation,  Bob. Ever. How many ways can I make  that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't just send me away!  I've read your book, I've been doing  what you told me, but I've completely  relapsed! A little time would mean  so much. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, I'm driving away now and I don't  want you to bother me again. You  came for my advice, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take my advice and go back to  New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't go anywhere! I'm all  locked up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got yourself here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting back will therapeutic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob starts begging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please just talk to me. Just a little  talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're testing my patience, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teeny tiny talk. An itty bitty  talk...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR, WHAT THE FAMILY SEES
dialogues.text: Bob is kneeling in front of Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty please... Pretty please with  sugar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family exchanges quizzical looks.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOB AND MARVIN
dialogues.text: Marvin looks around, incredibly embarrassed. He tugs at t kneeling Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gritted teeth) Get up. Come on, get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) Say you will. Please, say you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, it's two o'clock. Go to the bus  station, buy a ticket home, then  wait in that restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to "GUTTMAN'S" coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll meet me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you. (looks at his watch) In two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, you're the greatest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob moves to hug Marvin and Marvin reluctantly lets him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you must buy your ticket and  give your word that you'll go home.  This is all about trust again, Bob.  We must have trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust. I absolutely trust. I'll go  buy my ticket. Right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you at four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't possibly make it three  thirty, could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four it is. Four o'clock exactly.  Thank you, Dr. M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob starts across the parking lot as Marvin gets in the c and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car pulls out of the parking lot, Marvin's family  turns to look at Bob. Bob smiles and waves at the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, you look disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that poor man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is looking out the back window at Bob. She waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin hits the accelerator, leaving rubber.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUTTMAN'S COFFEE SHOP, LATER
dialogues.text: An ELDERLY COUPLE tend to the counters and glasses. Bob p by the phone, reading Baby Steps to himself. The clock on the wall reads three o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step to four o'clock. Baby step  to four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob covers his eyes then looks at the clock. No luck.  Frustrated, Bob paces again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel good, I feel great, I feel  four o'clock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again he looks at the clock: three-o-one. The elderly cou watch. They speak with thick European accents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny, your fishy's losing air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your guppy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks at Gil. The baggie is dripping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks for something to do about the dripping baggie. Guttman brings a glass and dumps Gil in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there something we can help you  with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you make it four o'clock? Dr.  Marvin's supposed to call me then  but I'm going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Dr. Leo Marvin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bought our dream house. We worked  a lifetime, saved up for a down  payment, then he swooped down with  his fancy schmancy lawyers and grabbed  it out from under us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay as far away from him as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the plague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. I'm his patient but he  doesn't want me near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll show you where he lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin and Siggy march to the end of the Marvin dock. The is a diving board. Siggy stands in a black terry robe and flip flops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take off your robe. Everything you  wear is black. I wish you'd get off  this death fixation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy reluctantly takes off his black robe. Under it he w a black t-shirt and black bathing suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know it's a death fixation?  Maybe I'm in mourning for my lost  childhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean by asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, get on the board and let's  see your approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (striking a pose) My approach is to be suave and  debonair and sophisticated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Siggy. 1, 2, 3 spring. Like  we learned last time. 1, 2, 3, spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy reluctantly mounts the board. He stands, feet toget then takes a step with his right foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1, 2, 3 spring. 1, 2, 3 summer. 1,  2, 3 fall. Time to go dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out, Siggy. Left foot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is no fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy sighs then starts again. He awkwardly takes two ste then stops at the end of the board, staring into the wate afraid to dive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you dive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all the horror that's going on  in the world, what difference does  it make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The decor is New England cottage-y with a strong dose of Marvin: incredibly ordered. On a pedestal is a bust of Si Freud. On the mantle sit the family puppets: -- Anna, Sig Fay, and Leo. Anna is at the family stereo, selecting a C Fay is on the chordless phone at the kitchen window, givi milk to some stray cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm excited Ellie. The  last person they interviewed on  vacation was Dr Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy enters and walks upstairs. Marvin enters and heads the living room chair. Fay hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't dive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a little afraid of it, dear.  Have patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like I'm making him jump  out of an airplane. When I was growing  up, I thought diving was fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were born grown up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stares at Anna. She puts on raucous heavy metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're masking hostility, Anna Marvin.  Turn that down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's full of Freudian symbols, dad.  It's educational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns down the volume, sits in his big easy chair, then takes a deep breath. He picks up Freud's Understandi Dreams. Anna puts on headphones and dances around wildly. Marvin tries to read. Suddenly a face appears in the wind It is Bob. He sees Marvin and taps on the window. Marvin  looks up and sees Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...? (he bolts to the front  door) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stands holding Gil (in the glass) and his bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Don't be mad. The Guttmans  brought me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob turns and waves at the Guttmans who are walking into OLD TRAILER that occupies next lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr. and Mrs. G.!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your welcome, Bobby, Hello, Dr.  Marvin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guttmans wave. Marvin waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burn in hell, Dr. Marvin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin's hand falls. The Guttmans enter their trailer. Ma turns to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We agreed that I would call you.  Your coming here is unbelievably  inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your picture. I'm Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Fay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. M. You're even prettier  than your picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through his teeth) Bob, I think you and I have some  things to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do? You finally think so too?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fay) Would you excuse us, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, may I take your fish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob hands Gil to Fay and she walks into the kitchen. Anna just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna rolls her eyes and follows her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin leads Bob away. Bob sees the puppets on the mantle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Marvin enter the downstairs study. Marvin indicat for Bob to take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great place. No wonder the Guttmans  wanted it. I really feel bad about  barging in like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do. Your problems don't  go away just because I go on vacation.  They've been with you a long time  after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever since I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand, you're making  strides. You got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I baby stepped. I owe it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob smiles. Marvin stares at Bob for a long time then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, take a look around you. What  does everything you see have in  common?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er... I don't know... It's all owned  by you, that's obvious. Humm...  Everything's from a garage sale!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause. Marvin stares at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation, Bob. Everything you see is  part of a vacation. Every year, for  one month, I bring my family to this  house on vacation. Nice, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wonderful. The lake. The trees.  The little town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what the point of a  vacation is? Do you understand the  meaning of the word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forget about your troubles. You  give up your worries. You drink from  the wellspring of relaxation that  enriches your soul. (pause) Now I can't, at this time, give you  the kind of therapeutic attention  that you need to solve all your  problems. Know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, because you're on vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. But what I can do -- and  only I can do this because you trust  me don't you Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why else would I be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. What I can do is this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin goes to a drawer and pulls out a prescription pad. writes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on your bus and go back to New  York. Every time a problem comes up,  follow this prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up his bag) I don't need pills. I have plenty of  pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin tears off a prescription sheet and hands it to bob

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not pills. Read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it) It says: "A vacation from my  problems."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving you permission to take a  vacation, Bob. Not a vacation from  your work. Not a vacation from your  daily life. But a vacation from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time you feel a problem coming  on, take that out and follow it to  the letter. Doctors orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctors orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you came. I'll see you in  my office next month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came here for relief, Bob. Read  your prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stands a moment, looking at his prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is... INCREDIBLE! This is  ASTOUNDING!! For the first time since  Menningers I feel free! I knew coming  up here was the right thing to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels right because you're here  and because you're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob comes over and hugs Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've given me a great gift, doctor.  The gift of life. You're a great  man.

dialogues.speaker: EXT.-INT. THE MARVIN HOUSE, DAY
dialogues.text: Marvin opens the door for Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have any questions, call Dr.  Harmon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a great vacation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vacation from my problems. You bet  I will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob exits. Marvin closes the door and looks up at the cei He takes a deep breath then turns back into the room. The is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Bob. I forgot Gil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob strides into the kitchen and takes his fish. Sigmund, now in his clothes, enters from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Sigmund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy, this is Bob. He's just leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. This is Gil. My fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. Did you get him out of the  lake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He's a city fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father is the most incredible  psychiatrist in the world! You better  appreciate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides to the door then turns wistfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a great vacation, fam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A WOODED LANE IN WINNIPESAUKEE, DAY
dialogues.text: Bob walks down the country lane. Crickets chirp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation from my problems. Take a  vacation from my problems. A baby  stepping, lazy stepping vacation  from my problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob falls into a rhythm, almost a little jig as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAKE WINNIPESAUKEE, MORNING
dialogues.text: Roosters crow in the new day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin, Fay and Siggy stand frozen, like artist's models, staring at something. Is this suddenly a Godard movie? Ar we now in a Becket play? Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too close to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin moves to the couch and pulls it out from the wall  about three inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I care, and you should too. Our house  is going on national television  tomorrow. You want your friends to  think you live in a dump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends would respect me for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there's nothing wrong with  neatness. People joke but it's  actually a sign of a creative  intelligence. Right, Fay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In isolated cases, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room looks wonderful, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay pecks him on the cheek and walks into the kitchen. Si follows. Ditto Anna who starts cooking pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, what do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets no answer from the rest of the family who look at each other and smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're incredibly creative, daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin goes back to making minuscule adjustments: adjusti diplomas, etc. At the front door is a knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it. It's probably the van  with my art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checking out his "set" as he goes, Marvin opens the door. It's Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning! I'll bet you're  surprised to see me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I walked out of here last night  I said to myself, "Dr. Marvin's  absolutely right. Take a vacation  from your problems. Blow em off.  Just say 'no'." So I did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... You're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. I'm taking a vacation.  This isn't an appointment, I'm  dropping by. I told the Guttmans  what you said and they found me a  cottage nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the town is packed but I guess  if you know the right people...  Anyway, I know we can't work but  let's get the friendship thing going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin is absolutely flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little anxious about being  here by myself but I don't want to  barge in. I'll call. Give my best to  the fam and see ya around, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob walks away. Marvin closes the door. He stands there f a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that, Leo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door. Marvin opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost forgot, here's your  newspaper. See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin takes the newspaper and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't that Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another knock on the door. It's Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys up for going out to  breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating in. I admire that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin slams the door in Bob's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Bob! I thought you said he  left town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I said exactly that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna moves to the front door, after Bob. Marvin grabs her arm and leads her to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't want you letting him in  this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, you're hurting me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna wrenches her arm away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, who is that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody, Fay. Nothing to get excited  about. A work related problem just  went away. (smiles nonchalantly) It's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
