dialogues.text: He strolls off into the kitchen. Anna rubs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen him like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) If you want to know, I think your  father is nervous about going on  national television tomorrow. Freud  himself would be anxious so let's be  supportive, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should go punch some pillows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or get shock treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that he's under pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flap jacks!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A WOODED LANE IN WINNIPESALRKEE, DAY
dialogues.text: Bob walks down the empty country lane. Crickets chirp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation from my problems. Take a  vacation from my problems. There's  nothing to fear, there's nobody here.  Nothing to fear (he suddenly panics) THERE'S NOBODY HERE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts running and screaming.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN SUMMER HOUSE, MORNING
dialogues.text: TWO MEN from a van are bringing in the art from Marvin's  office. Marvin is using a weed trimmer to spruce up the s to within an inch or their lives. Anna, in a bathing suit sunglasses, and skimpy cover-up exits the house, gives he father a good-bye peck on the cheek then gets in the fami station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you off to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Teddy Fein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. George Stark. The boy from the  plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a quarter mile to the marina.  Why do you need the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm picking everybody up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts the car and backs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of the sun! Remember what's  happening to the ozone layer.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A WOODED LANE IN WINNIPESAUKEE, DAY
dialogues.text: Bob is running in a panic. Anna drives by and sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna hits the brakes and slows next to Bob. He breaks to slow trot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to... town. (pause) Buy some..., Kleenex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think your dad would like  you picking me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't like a lot of things.  Hop in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob hesitates then gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna drives. Bob puts on his seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seemed pretty upset this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's nervous about the interview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interview?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria Shriver's coming tomorrow to  talk about his book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow... so that's the problem! And I  thought he was upset about me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's always uptight, even when  it doesn't show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Imagine growing up with a dad  who sees every stage of growing up  as a Freudian passage. Did you ever  have crayons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat or skinny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, skinny, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warning tone) Uh oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad saw crayons as phallic symbols.  When I asked for skinny crayons, it  was a personal assault on his manhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he do, buy a Porsche?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish! He just kept psychoanalyzing  everything. My dolls were alter egos.  Boys who wanted to kiss me were  Oedipally fixated adolescents looking  to displace their mothers on their  aboriginal family totems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like my friends to a tee. (a beat) You seem to be doing okay now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly. I analyze everything to death.  Every time a guy smiles at me, I ask  myself is he really smiling or is he  just orally fixated? When I smile  back, I wonder, am I really attracted  or just smiling out of some residual  Cro-Magnon instinct? If I ever  actually have sex, I'm not sure I'll  know the difference between an orgasm  and an anxiety attack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the same problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kinds of urges other girls act  on impulsively, I analyze until either  the urge goes away or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy goes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. It sounds like your dad never  learned to leave his work at the  office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot of good it does me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll make some man very happy  someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hangs in the air. Anna looks at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buying Kleenex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna come sailing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I... I, er...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. You don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks at Anna. He sees her attraction to him and it m him nervous but he doesn't want to reject her. He looks d shyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's not that I don't want  to go. It's just that I've never  been on a boat and I'm not sure I  can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to it. George Stark's  doing the sailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just thinking about gives me hives.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Standing next to the mast, his hair blowing in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, this is great! I never  actually thought I could do this. I  never thought this could be me!

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: That Bob, wearing life preservers on his body and legs, i wrapped onto the mast from chest to toe with ropes. Anna, George Stark (from the airport) and a few other kids sit  around enjoying the sail.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN PRIVATE DOCK, DAY
dialogues.text: Marvin stands at the end of the diving board, holding Sig by his ankles out over the water. On the shore next door, the Guttmans sit in lounge chairs, fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is child abuse! If you drop me,  I'll prosecute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not going to let go until you're  ready, okay? Trust me and put your  hands out like I showed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ready! Do you hear? I'm not  ready!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's sailboat heels by. From it wave Anna and some of her friends -- and Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting and waving) Hey Doctor M, look at me! I'm sailing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, Marvin drops Siggy into the water. Siggy does a  belly flop then comes up for air, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderer! Child molester...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy, it was an accident!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. A PIER NEAR WINNIPESAUKEE TOWN, LATER
dialogues.text: Marvin walks along the shore towards the pier in time to Anna and a wobbly Bob disembark George's sailboat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sees her father. She says good-bye to George and her friends then walks towards her father. Bob starts towards Marvin too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see me out there?! I'm getting  better all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see Anna alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stops. Marvin waits while Anna walks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I told you to stay away  from Bob Wiley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You just said I couldn't let him  in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin starts walking away from the sailboating party tow the town green. He puts his arm around Anna so that she h to walk with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the car? I left it at the  pier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it. It's been a while since  I've had a walk with my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks back at her friends and Bob. She shrugs then t back to her father. From his pockets Marvin removes the L and Anna puppets and hands her "Anna".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, not here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, I know you think you're old  enough to know what's best for you  and I know you're at the age where  you don't want to listen to your  father. But as your father, who's  always loved you, I'm asking you not  to see Bob Wiley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna grabs the Anna puppet and puts it on, defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand the problem! Bob's  a nice guy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Wiley is a patient. He followed  me here from New York which is  bizarre. But even if it weren't  bizarre, my daughter seeing a patient  that I'm treating is entirely  inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob said you're not treating him  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if you're not treating him while  he's here, then he's not a patient  while he's here, is he? And I have  the right to see him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws the puppet at Marvin then runs to her friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, you're acting out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's a perfectly nice guy! He's  intense and sensitive and he listens  which is more than I can say about  you. Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stands a moment and watches. He is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, come back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna runs to Bob and takes his arm. They start walking do the shore. Marvin is dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. THE MARVIN HOUSE, LATER
dialogues.text: Siggy lies on the deck, looking up at the sky through  binoculars. Fay is in the kitchen, arranging driftwood. S comes to the back door of the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come in and talk about  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because your father dropped you  in the water doesn't mean you can't  trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sleep with him. You're his spy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin enters, looking absolutely stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, you've upset Siggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stares blankly at Fay then shuffles up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again Marvin doesn't answer and Fay starts towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, go to him! You always  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay stops, looks at Siggy then goes upstairs after Leo.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE DECK, DAY
dialogues.text: Siggy lies back down and peers through the binoculars. As does, a grotesque CLOSE UP OF BOB pops into Siggy's field view. He sits up with a start. Bob and Anna are standing  over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Siggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi, Bob. You scared me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Didn't mean to sneak up on  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy lies back down and looks through the binoculars, cl not interested in being social. Bob looks at Anna. She sh her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's at it again. I can tell. (to Siggy) Another vacation that's not a  vacation, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with him and diving? Maria  Shriver's not gonna watch me dive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin is prostrate on the bed, Marvin puppet still on hi hand, staring at the ceiling. Fay enters. She sits down n to Marvin and strokes his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, Siggy is really upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin looks at his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay, I'm a failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our daughter, our only daughter, has  fallen for a brilliant manipulator  twice her age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, for god's sake talk sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy is standing on the diving board, ready for his appr Bob and Anna watch from the pier. Next door the Guttmans watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face a fear and it goes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm facing it, now what do I  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit it. Fast. While it isn't looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy takes a deep breath, summons up his courage, and ma his approach. He springs but can't dive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mind says "yes yes" but my body  says "no no". It's hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm not hopeless, nothing's  hopeless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob steps onto the board. He "baby steps" out to the end  where Siggy is standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try something I saw in a pirate  movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin is down the hall in the bathroom, dousing his face with water. Fay stands in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, I'm even a failure  in my own book! Can you believe it?  In Chapter 2, I wrote that a healthy  adolescent girl can never have a  sublimated father complex and my  daughter has one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a brief flirtation, honey. Anna's  perfectly healthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're saying the book's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better that than Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin washes his face some more then looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay, my god!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin walks into the room, water dripping off his face,  looking like a man who's just seen his own death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, what? Leo, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going on national television  tomorrow -- to promote a fraud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is standing near the end of the diving board holding  Siggy by the hips. Siggy is hanging over the water, hands and head down, ready to enter the water diving. Anna is  watching. So are the Guttmans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think about boiling oil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or searing acid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Father, we commit this soul to  the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob gently releases Siggy. Siggy falls into the water, di Anna applauds. So do the Guttmans. Siggy resurfaces and t a jubilant fist in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay holds Marvin's head in her bosom, stroking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doomed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be a laughing stock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you won't. You've blow this way  out of proportion, Leo, and you have  to get control. Now try your  breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (breathes hard) I'm being ridiculous. (more breaths) You're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks around breathing exaggeratedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a brilliant book... Our  daughter's fine... I'm great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause from outside can be heard in the room. Fay goes the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay, do you remember a Carswell  Fensterwald?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, Leo, look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name is so familiar but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, Siggy's diving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin looks out the window. He sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob releases Siggy for another perfect dive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put a stop to this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin storms out of the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy stands at the end of the board, more confident now, getting ready to do another dive. Bob holds Siggy again b this time Siggy doesn't need much help if any. Marvin cha down the dock, Fay right behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough. Let go of him! That's enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. M., watch this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning over to dive) Watch, dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop diving this instant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin leaps onto the diving board, shaking it. Bob loses his grip and Siggy falls off the board, doing a back bust Bob falls in too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! (daggers at Marvin) You bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo! Look at what you're doing! Leo,  look at yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody looks at Marvin, standing alone on the board. H realizes that he's lost all control, something he never d He looks at the Guttmans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you staring at? I had every  right to buy this house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking in the water) Where's Bob? Where's Bob?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Fay dive into the water. They go under looking f Bob.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN HOUSE DECK, AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Bob is off a bit by himself, wringing out his clothes. Fa Anna and Siggy sit toweling off. Marvin comes out of the  house and talks in low tones to his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, everybody, I'm not wrong  often, but when I am, I admit it.  I'm sorry. I mean it. How can I make  it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause. Anna and Siggy and Fay look at each oth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knocking Bob in the water was awful.  What if he hadn't known how to swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he did. I'm not saying I was  right, but Bob can do a lot of things  no one thought he could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, Fay and Siggy are silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I said I was wrong now I'd  like to forget it. I'd like you all  to accept my apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Bob?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think you should apologize  to him?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: at the outdoor shower, rinsing off his clothes. He can't  hear the family but he can see they're talking about him he's giving them his best hang-dog looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not apologize to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, why are you so hostile towards  the poor man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's a patient, Fay! Don't  you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a patient, he's a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a nice one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should invite him for  dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor fellow's devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay heads towards Bob. Marvin turns to her. He keeps his  voice low to keep from being heard by Bob, but inside he about to explode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want Bob for dinner, Fay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want Bob for dinner, Fay. I  want to think about my interview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo is trying not to explode. Fay hangs in the balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it, mom. Invite him. You'd be  making family history. It'd be the  first major thing you've done on  your own since I've known you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right is right, Leo Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay heads to Bob. Marvin's mouth falls open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Testing 1, 2, 3. Testing. For the  next few seconds we will be conducting  a test of the emergency broadcast  system:

dialogues.speaker: MARVIN SIGGY
dialogues.text: Fay talks to Bob. Anna heads over to him too. Marvin stan speechless, ready to commit hari-kari.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN HOUSE PATIO, EVENING
dialogues.text: Dusk has descended over Lake Winnipesaukee. The glow of t moon, the stars, and lights from the other cottages along the lake shore provide peaceful illumination. The Marvin  family -- and Bob -- are dining out on their deck overloo the lake. Marvin sits silent, holding in his anger. Bob,  swinging at occasional moths, sits next to Siggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away. Get away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ring around the moon. Rain coming  soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (edgy to Siggy) Gee, is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's superstitious nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Fay exit the cottage carrying trays of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fay and Anna) That looks scrumptious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles and hands the first plate of food to Bob. Mar sees this and crosses his arms. He shoots a death stare a Anna. She defiantly shoots it right back. Bob sees this  exchange of looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Bob. It's fine. Eat up. Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay looks at Marvin and shakes her head "no".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating) Mmmm. Mmmmm. This sure is good. Mmmm.  Mmmmm. Mmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you please stop that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry, Leo. Would you pass the  salt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't call me Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. You said in your office  that I could call you Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was in my office. In my home  you will call me Dr. Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin snaps the salt down next to Bob. Bob looks helples at Fay. Fay puts a hand on Bob's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) He's nervous about the interview  tomorrow. Don't take it personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Marvin) Hey, that's right, I heard about  your upcoming debut. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin nods and eats. Bob throws salt over his shoulder t salts his food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your book's going to do a lot of  people a lot of good, Le-- Dr. Marvin.  I'm walking proof of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin chokes on the food he's eating. Siggy slaps his da on the back. Marvin keeps coughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns red and points to his throat. He falls to th deck on his side. Bob stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't panic! I know what to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob hurries to Marvin, lies beside him, and administers t Heimlick maneuver. On the second try, Marvin's throat cle Marvin lies in Bob's arms, coughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin says something. Fay leans over him to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said..., get him off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob lets go of Marvin. Marvin coughs and crawls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, you saved him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible! Wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay helps Marvin gets to his feet. Suddenly, there is a f of lightning. Bob jumps. Rain begins to fall. Marvin look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told you so.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MARVIN HOUSE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The rain outside is coming down in buckets. Marvin is in living room, re-straightening the furniture and art ever meticulously. He adjusts a diploma over the mantle. Anna, Fay, Siggy and Bob are in the kitchen, doing the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm singing in the rain, Just singing  in the rain, What a glorious feeling,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob throws his pack of Kleenex into the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob retrieves the pack of Kleenex from the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I walk though the kitchen With a  bowl full of chicken (puts the chicken in  the fridge) I'm singing, I'm singing In the rain."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Fay and Siggy start a dance. Marvin enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, tomorrow morning is very  important and I'd like to call it a  night. I don't want to be rude but I  think it's time for Bob to sing his  way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the rain) Honey, you don't expect Bob to walk  back in this do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say that? I'll drive him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car's still in town, daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said to leave it, remember? We  walked home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin seethes then looks darkly at Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain's bound to let up. Bob can  go then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it starts up again while  Bob's on the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nastily) He can borrow my slicker.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MARVIN LIVING ROOM, LATE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Marvin stands staring out the window like he'd like to mu the rain that is still coming down in torrents. Bob is on the couch, sitting alone, wearing Marvin's yellow slicker looking unwanted. Anna, Siggy and Fay sit quietly, watchi Marvin. Bob looks at Fay and shrugs like he's sorry. Fay  puts a sympathetic hand on Bob's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. It's letting up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a crash of thunder that shakes the rafters. Marv reaches out and slowly scratches the window, creating a t squeaking sound. Fay walks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Leo, we can't make the poor fellow  sit here all night. Let's let him  stay over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay over? Honey, Maria Shriver's  coming in the morning. Maria Shriver!  You want some guy sleeping on our  couch when Maria Shriver gets here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He almost laughs at the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an extra bed in Siggy's room.  Bob, would you like to spend the  night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I... Do you have a dacron pillow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a great idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure I'm not imposing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you are -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- aren't. Anna, find an extra set  of sheets. Siggy, get one of your  father's robes for Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay shoots Marvin a dirty look then exits the room with A Marvin claws the window making a bone chilling squeak.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SIGGY'S ROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Siggy's room has twin beds arranged head to head against corner. Bob, wearing one of Marvin's robes, enters. Siggy hanging up his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find a toothbrush?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (belches and hits his  chest) Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You care which bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd prefer facing southeast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin enters in his pj's. Fay is preparing for bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen my new toothbrush?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should be in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it should be but it's not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay shoots Marvin a dirty look then heads towards the  bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because you're nervous about  tomorrow, Leo Marvin, doesn't give  you the right to get snippy. If you  can't handle the pressure, postpone  the interview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay, it's not the interview -- I  mean I am nervous about it -- but  that's not what's bugging me. It's...  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him who? Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Siggy. Yes, Bob! Who else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, quiet. He'll hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why shouldn't he hear me? Don't you  get it, he's a sick person. A  multiphobic mess! He faked suicide...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that a cry for help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Followed me up here from New York,  wormed his way into my house. For  all I know, he's a mass murderer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Leo, he's a sweet guy.  Perfectly harmless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that! Everything he's  done violates the patient-doctor  relationship. Now he's in there with  our son!

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE SIGGY'S BEDROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob and Siggy lie in Siggy's twin beds. Outside, lightnin flashes. Bob chews his nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you go to dad? Are you really  sick or just maladjusted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick. You ever had a bee buzz your  face that wouldn't go away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Once or twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was twelve, I had one buzz me  for three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning strikes again. Bob bites his nails. He stands a paces a bit. He notices some books in Siggy's bookcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. You got some heavy stuff here.  Denial of Death, Fear and Trembling,  Sickness Unto Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are dad's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets you read this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hid them but I found them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks in one, shudders, then puts it back on the shel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you afraid of death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do about it? I mean, how  do you cope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... The way I figure it, if it  weren't called "death", it wouldn't  be so bad. I mean what if it were  called "dink"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it would be fine. We'd say  "Grandma dinked." "The garbage man  dinked."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My turtle just dinked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Then we wouldn't worry  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course we'd still have to worry  about Barrett's Esophagus and Black  Water Fever and Tourette's Syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Tourette's syndrome?

dialogues.speaker: INT. FAY AND MARVIN'S BEDROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fay and Leo lie near sleep. Suddenly, from the other room comes a loud barrage of profanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FART BRAIN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOGER HEAD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DONKEY DICK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay and Marvin spring out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SIGGY'S ROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob and Siggy are jumping up and down on their beds, spou profanity at each other. Marvin and Fay rush in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on in here?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Siggy jump under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you a question!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tourette's Dad. You know, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dad... Leo... Dr. Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin glares at Bob. Fay nudges Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kids being kids, Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear another peep  out of this room. I'm trying to get  some sleep around here! Tomorrow is  the most important day of my career!  CBS is coming here. Maria Shriver is  coming here. Millions will be  watching. And buying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Dad. We'll stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got carried away. We won't do it  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stares at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you out by six thirty.  Understand. Maria Shriver comes at  seven, I want you out by six thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Would you like something for  sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got Valium if you need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need Valium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halcyon? Seconal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need peace and quiet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll be peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob nudges Siggy and they try to contain their laughter.  Marvin glares at them then storms out. Fay comes up and t them into their beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault, Mrs. M., we should  have been quieter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just have to get him through Maria  Shriver. Sleep tight. Don't let the  bed bugs bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bed bugs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just an expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh right. 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns out the light and pulls the door closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. M!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind leaving it cracked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay smiles and leaves the door cracked.

dialogues.speaker: LAKE WINNIPESAUKEE, EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: A clearing storm, right after dawn. Three vans from "CBS  Morning" wind along the lake towards town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see Siggy and Bob sound asleep in t beds. DOLLY ACROSS the clapboards to Leo and Fay's room w Fay lies sound asleep and Marvin lies looking at his watc It lets out a series of beeps and he stands and exits. DO back to Siggy's room where Marvin knocks, loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six o'clock, rise and shine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy sits up. Bob doesn't stir. Marvin enters, watch bee and walks to Bob. He puts the watch next to Bob's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise and shine. Six o'clock. Rise  and shine, rise and shine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob doesn't move. Fay and Anna enter in robes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob... Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes Bob's bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob sleeps through incredible shaking and yelling from a  desperate Marvin then suddenly sits up with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody leaps back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MARVIN HOUSEHOLD, EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Marvin is in the living room, dressed in his stiffest cas from L.L. Bean, nervously adjusting his "set". Fay is in kitchen, preparing food. Momentarily, Bob comes bounding  down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more and more rapidly) Baby stepping down the stairs. Baby  stepping down the stairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and sees Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello! Is this a beautiful day or  what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin walks to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gritted teeth) Leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had the most incredible dream last  night, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this something you want me to  work out on my own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. You've been right about  everything so far. God, therapy is a  fascinating process. 'Bye Mrs. M.  Thank you for everything. 'Bye Anna.  See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye Bob. See you later today, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me. I won't. (towards the upstairs) So long, ass wipe of the universe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming to the railing  upstairs) 'Bye dog pissing barf brain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siggy! Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob exits out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, fart smelling douche bag! (beat) Maria Shriver's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns red in the face. He walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIA SHRIVER and her entourage - PRODUCER, DIRECTOR, vid crew, etc. -- approach the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin, Maria Shriver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swallows nervously) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope we're not too early. May we  come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin steps aside. The crew enters with equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I thought by the fireplace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a fireplace shot, fellows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob walks to the side screen door, pushes his nose to it watches. Marvin sees this and motions Bob away with his h Bob waves back. Two men approach Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the Director, Howie Katrell.  This is Lenny Burns, our Producer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin shakes their hands. Maria admires the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is even nicer than the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. This is my wife, er, Fay.  My daughter Anna, and my son...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin is so nervous, he's forgotten Siggy's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Siggy, dad. How's Arnold? Can  you get me his autograph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sigmund...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can swing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria looks at Bob who is still standing in the screen do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the screen door and shakes her hand. This done,  Marvin closes the screen door on Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's a patient. He was just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. A Baby Stepper in action. Neat  idea. Howie, Dr. Marvin's gonna have  a patient on with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Let's can the fireplace shot  and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait just a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. We can still use the  fireplace. Phil, what say we set up  over there and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob opens the screen door and walks back in. Marvin sees  this and can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Shriver, --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the more I think about this,  Doctor, the more I love it. I mean  who better to testify to the  effectiveness of your book than one  of your patients. I think it's a two  parter, Lenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do to. Great idea, Dr. Marvin.  Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps a disbelieving Marvin on the back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MARVIN LIVING ROOM, MORNING
dialogues.text: The room is bright lit for TV and the crew is making last minute adjustments. Marvin and Bob sit on the couch, both nervous wrecks, Bob clutching his copy of Baby Steps and air sickness bag, Marvin clutching a copy of his book.  Marvin's diplomas and art are displayed prominently on th "set". The proud family looks on. Fay leans in with a lin roller, rolls Marvin's shirt, kisses him, and backs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live feed in ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock em dead, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie, I don't like that there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crew person rushes up and takes down Marvin's diploma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five -- four -- three --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I use the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie points at Maria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Morning. We're live in the  beautiful Lake Winnipesaukee summer  home of Dr. Leo M. Marvin, author of  the newest sensation in therapy,  Baby Steps. Also with us is Dr.  Marvin's patient, Bob Wiley. Good  morning, Dr. Marvin. Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin shoots Bob a dirty look. Bob smiles innocently.  Suddenly Bob takes out his air sickness bag and holds it as if to throw up in it. After a long beat, Bob puts it b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: False alarm. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob smiles. Marvin turns beet red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Marvin, it takes a remarkable  amount of confidence in your methods  to bring on a patient with you. What  in particular about Bob's prior  condition would you like to share  with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin looks at Bob. A tiny, sadistic smile comes across face. There are a million things he'd like to say about B to humiliate him, punish him, discredit him, ridicule him vilify him, pillory him -- on national TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing? Nothing in particular you  think we should know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hum... Well... (pause) Let me try you, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at Bob. Bob takes out his air sickness bag aga He holds it for a long time then puts it away. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been a patient of Dr.  Marvin's for a long time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time? I wouldn't call it a long  time. (looking at Marvin) What? Three or four days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Days?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carswell Fensterwald sits watching Marvin and Bob on TV.  Marvin is a bumbling wreck, trying to save this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... you see... I was..., he was...  I was..., following his case  through..., another psychiatrist...  He thought I was, er, the perfect  doctor for the case. Because of my  book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you sly dogs, he was right! I  want to say that if more wisdom, or  more empathy, or more pure  intelligence exists than exits in  this man, I want to know about it.  Do you know that he actually had me  sleep here last night? In his jamies,  using his toothbrush!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a very unusual technique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fensterwald pounds his chair and howls with glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say and I've been to them all.  Doctors who made you beat pillows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He demonstrates by beating a couch pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctors who make you scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob suddenly screams. Marvin jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this doctor has something simple.  Baby Steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob holds up Baby Steps then stands and walks back and fo in front of Marvin. He holds the book so that it can be s by the TV camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby step across the room. Baby step  across the room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans and looks into the TV camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you getting the book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob plops back on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you what I used to be  like before I met Dr M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob puts his arm around Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven years ago I was not the man  you see today. Eleven years ago...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN HOUSE, MORNING
dialogues.text: The CBS vans are loading up. Maria, Lenny and Howie stand the door saying good-by. Marvin hovers in the background, shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, that stuff about yourself was  refreshingly honest. Could we talk  to you again in a few months to update  your progress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. As long as my doctor gives  permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin tries to force a smile but can't. A CBS staff  photographer comes over, places Bob and Maria in his fram and snaps a picture. The CBS people head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for your hospitality, Mrs.  Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anytime!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria and CBS leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family and Bob move back into the house. Looking like zombie, Leo closes the door. He stands still for a long  moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... ruined!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruined?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My career... Everything I've worked  for..., over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin ambles across the room like a cripple. The family  watches in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But daddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Marvin turns on Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it something, I said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin moves at Bob, backing him towards the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GET OUT!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing Marvin's rage, Bob backs out and Marvin closes the door. After a moment there's a knock. Marvin opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this aversion therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO AWAY NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin slams the door again. The family is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My god, Leo, what's got into you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you're over reacting. What about  Bob?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CRIS CRAFT BOAT, DAY
dialogues.text: The doctors and their wives sit rapt, listening to Doctor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what about Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT ABOUT BOB?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, look at your behavior. What  are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I doing? What am I doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides across the room. He finds his electronic organ opens it, and pushes buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday... Afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out the organizer for family to see the readout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going sailing!

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COUNTRY ROAD, DAY
dialogues.text: Bob walks down the road, upset, talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fam is hurt. I've hurt them. I  didn't mean to. Certainly they realize  that. I've hurt the fam. Hurt the  fam. I've hurt the fam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marvin station wagon, Marvin driving, passes. Bob see Fay, Siggy, and Anna turn and wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi fam! (pause) Bye fam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car speeds on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hurt the fam.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE WINNIPESAUKEE PIER, DAY
dialogues.text: Marvin's family climbs aboard a small sailboat. Marvin pu a line onto the deck, then the boat glides out into the l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob wanders, looking lost, mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could apologize. But then I'd have  to go back and I'm not sure they  want me. I hurt the fam. That much I  know. Hurt the fam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot dog, bub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks idly up. A VENDOR with a cart is talking to Bob

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VENDOR hands Bob a hot dog. Bob hands him money then  wanders off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Families of tourists stroll. Bob stands staring dejectedl out at the lake. Unthinkingly, he takes a bite of the hot dog then turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has to be some kind of test. I  know I hurt them but they have to  know I didn't mean it. If it's a  test... I ate a hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stares at the hot dog like it just spoke Greek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ATE A HOT DOG!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tourists turn and stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin stands at the helm, sailing the small sailboat acr lake. The breeze blows Marvin's hair, making him look wil Anna suns. Siggy casts a fishing line. Fay stares into  nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it's summer time right, what  could their audience be, five million?  Most of them hardly pay attention  anyway, right? The point is, the  book got on. It couldn't hurt sales,  that much could it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean... It's a disaster, Fay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look. Isn't that Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off the bow, a small motorboat is approaching.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOTORBOAT, SAME
dialogues.text: Bob is steering a small motorboat towards the sailboat. H holds half of his hot dog out like a trophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. M! Dr. M., I've had a  breakthrough! I ate a hot dog! I'm  driving a boat! Thanks to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Bob! It's Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Siggy wave. Marvin's eyes narrow. Bob keeps shou as he motors closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really making progress now! I  feel like a whole new world is opening  up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps getting closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My childhood memories are rushing  over me like a flood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns the rudder and comes about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the sailboat and heads the opposite direction fr Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at Bob's boat) Go away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, he's trying to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin keeps sailing away. But Bob's boat is faster and i gaining. Marvin sees this, jerks the rudder again, and tu ninety degrees. He stands and shouts at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away, do you hear me!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, the boom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boom hits Marvin square in the chest, and knocks him  overboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy! Leo! Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin bobs in the water. The pilotless sailboat heels aw Bob dives in, swims to Marvin, and grabs him by the chin a traditional life-saver hold. As Siggy gains control of sailboat, Bob begins doing the side stroke towards the di shore with Marvin in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had a father, really. Dad  left one morning and never came back.  My earliest memory is mom with a  suitcase. Do you think that's  significant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin is a prisoner in tow. He drags himself under water Bob pulls him up and keeps swimming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to do some free association  about my infancy: A beachball. A  dog. A frog. A log. Poodle, noodle,  doodle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bob swims Marvin towards the shore, going on and on wi this inane free association...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN HOUSE, AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Marvin, dry and dressed now, exits the house and gets in station wagon. He honks. Momentarily Bob runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the house) Will do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob gets in the car. Affectless, Marvin stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever we're going, Fay wants us  home by seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin accelerates away, rudely.

dialogues.speaker: EXT./INT. THE MARVIN STATION WAGON, DAY
dialogues.text: Rain is falling. The wipers swish. Marvin drives through  pastoral New Hampshire countryside focused, perhaps too  intently, on the road. Bob sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a combustible relationship,  isn't it? Is it just you and me or  is it you and everybody? (pause) So what's the big surprise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intensive psychotherapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that what you came here for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! But what brought this on now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. This is exciting.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE TOMSKY CONVALESCENT HOME, DAY
dialogues.text: The rain has let up. Marvin pulls up to a gated estate  sporting expansive grounds and a hotel sized main buildin Marvin stops at a guard gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Marvin to see Dr. Tomsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GATE GUARD checks a list. He waves Marvin through. GA GUARD Main building doctor. They're expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therapy land, Bob. A twentieth century  theme park of the mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lines look short today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin gets out and so does Bob. A man Leo's age, DR. TOM approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Leo. Long time no see! Is  this our friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Wiley, this is your new pal, Dr.  Tomsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New pal? What's wrong with my old  pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomsky makes a motion of his head. Two big attendants mov to either side of Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us show you to your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lead Bob off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Don't touch me! I have seizures!  Dr. M! Dr. M!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take Bob into a building. Marvin turns to Tomsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really appreciate your helping me  out on this, Kenneth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomsky holds out a form for Marvin to sign. He does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only hold him for twenty four  hours, Leo. Without staff  corroboration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried in the least, Kenneth.  I'm sure your entire staff will  corroborate. With intensive treatment  he should be out in about -- fifty  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin hands the clipboard back to Tomsky. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN HOUSE DRIVEWAY, LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The Marvin station wagon pulls into the driveway, radio i blasting, playing a tape of Neil Diamond. Marvin exits it dancing as he sings along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'll be what I am, solitary man.  SOLITARY MAN!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin enters singing. Siggy and Anna see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to "Oklahoma") "Okay, Anna Mae, Leo Marvin's okay  Leo Marvin, he's okay!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, dad, where's Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't a man enjoy himself on vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob sends his regrets but he had to  take a trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of trip? I thought you  were working with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why'd he go on a trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does a man climb a mountain,  Anna? Because it's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns up the music and dances. Anna and Siggy stan stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't even say good-bye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like Bob not to say good- bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why he left, you see. He just  wasn't himself. (pause) He'll write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, if you did something to Bob...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, what do you take me for? (pause) Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin, looking perfectly content, turns off the music, g to his chair, picks up Freud's Understanding Dreams, the  book he's been trying to read since he arrived here. Sigg and Anna stare at him suspiciously. Fay enters carrying t cordless phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, a Dr. Tomsky says it's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin takes the phone and walks into the kitchen. Anna a Siggy look even more suspicious. Momentarily Leo strides of the kitchen and walks out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that? (pause) Be home by seven, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin doesn't answer because he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's rotten in Winnipesaukee.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE TOMSKY CONVALESCENT HOME, LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Marvin's car screeches up. Marvin hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob sits around a table with Tomsky and several members o the STAFF who are laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I've another one. Who knows  the difference between Freud and  Moses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees blank, expectant faces, waiting for a punchline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if you don't know, I'm going to  another clinic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All laugh. Tomsky sees Marvin enter and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So a psychiatrist and a psychologist  go into a bar and order Bloody  Marys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomsky joins Marvin in the hall. In the other room we see Bob continuing to joke with the staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenneth, you have been duped by a  textbook narcissist. A brilliant  neuropath!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant enough to dupe my entire  staff? I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomsky stuffs a paper into Marvin's shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving you back his admitting  forms, Leo, to save you any  embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embarrassment?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's perfectly natural for a patient  to bond with his analyst. It's a  normal part of therapy. If you want  to be rid of him, simply take him  back where you got him and go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's easy for you to say! He's  human crazy glue! If it were that  simple do you think I'd be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have never let him sleep  in your pajamas, Leo. His problems  don't go away just because you want  them too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose side are you on?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm relaxed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on vacation!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Maybe you should check  in here for a few days and get a  handle on things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin looks at Tomsky, amazed at the implication of this statement.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE COUNTRYSIDE OF NEW ENGLAND, DAY
dialogues.text: Marvin drives. Bob rides. Marvin looks ready to explode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intensive psychotherapy? -- boy, you  weren't kidding, were you? I mean  even Dr. T. didn't think I needed  that. (pause) Look I have an idea -- how are your  afternoons? I mean since we're here  together with nothing else to do,  what say we work from two to four,  something like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marvinmobile screeches to a halt and Marvin jumps out He rushes around the car and opens Bob's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out! Get out of my car, get out  of my life, don't ever come back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin drags Bob out of the car and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying you'd prefer mornings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin gets back in and floors it. He speeds off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, isolation therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stands alone on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds chirp and crickets crick. A pick-up truck passes an Bob sticks out his thumb. The pick-up stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin is about to bust a vessel. Telephone poles shoot b like pickets on a fence. Behind him a siren wails. In his rear-view mirror, Marvin sees a motorcycle cop approachin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! You won't catch me!! NO!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SIDE OF THE ROAD, ANOTHER SPOT, LATER
dialogues.text: The motorcycle cop is writing a steaming Leo Marvin a tic A passing pick-up slows and Bob leans out the passenger  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need any help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember: be home by seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pick-up drives on. The motorcycle cop hands Marvin a  ticket. Marvin gets back into his car, throws it in gear, and the car jerks backwards into the guardrail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin throws it into forward. The car, fender dented, te away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE PORCH OF A COUNTRY HOUSE, LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Sitting on the porch of his house, an OLD MAN watches as  Marvin's car slows to a stop out in the road. The tire un the dented fender is torn to ribbons by the metal and the car is now riding on the rim. Marvin stops, gets out of t car, and looks at the tire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First he ruins my life, now he ruins  my tire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cursing to himself, Marvin walks to the trunk and removes jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God! Damn! Son of a bitching! Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN comes out of the house and joins the old man. The watch in silence as Marvin jacks up his car. As he twists and grimaces and kicks to get off the lug nuts, it starts RAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit piss crap! Son of a bitching  douche bag asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE MORE PEOPLE come out on the porch and watch. As Mar struggles, the car slips off the jack and slams to the  pavement. Marvin begins kicking the tire and hitting it w the jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Bob?! Think about Bob!  What about Bob? What about Bob? WHAT  ABOUT BOB!!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE MARVIN HOUSE, DUSK
dialogues.text: Mumbling to himself, soaking wet, and filthy with tire gr Marvin walks to his house. He kicks open the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights go on. Thirty people stand around the room with pa favors and drinks. In unison they yell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise! (then sing:) "Happy Birthday to you, Happy Birthday  to you! Happy Birthd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The singing tapers into silence. Flabbergasted by Marvin' disheveled appearance, the party guests stare. Fay and th kids approach, tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, look at yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little car trouble, hon. I'm  fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay is speechless. So are Siggy and Anna. Not wanting to things sink, party-hardy well-wishers approach Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some night to have car trouble. You  almost missed your own surprise party!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, Dr. M!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin turns and stares at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't miss your birthday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin suddenly leaps at Bob and grabs him by the throat. pushes him through three rooms of the house, choking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you dead! Dead, you hear me,  dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin falls on the floor on top of Bob. Guests go to pul him off.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MARVIN BEDROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Marvin lies in bed in the darkened room. He can hear the  party guests huddle outside in the hall, whispering. A gu whom we recognize as the Doctor 3 from the boat, (the man who is telling this story), enters carrying his doctor's  bag. He approaches Fay who is wringing her hands. Both sp in whispers loud enough for Marvin to decipher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen him like this, Phil.  He's got this delusion about Bob  Wiley being the cause of all his  problems and I don't know what to  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's under a lot of stress, Fay. His  book, his interview which frankly  didn't go so well, his birthday.  That's a lot to bite off all at once.  I'll give him a sedative and he'll  be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil puts a hand on Fay's hand and nods.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE MARVIN LIVING ROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob sits on the couch beside Siggy. Anna approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feeling better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. It's your dad I'm worried  about. How is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs. Resting. I can't understand  why he'd attack you like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits next to Bob. Bob sees George Stark, standing ac the room, smiling at Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't either. But one thing I've  learned about psychiatrists: they're  brilliant manipulators. I trust your  dad completely. I'm sure everything  he's done has been to help me. (pause) How come you aren't making a move on  George Stark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at George) Bob, we've talked about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you've talked about it and I've  listened. In my opinion, George  Stark's smile is not Oedipal  regression and it's not confused  libido. It's one good looking guy  drooling over you, Anna Marvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ask if you can put your tongue in  his mouth. I hear it works every  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles then summons her courage, and smilingly appro George. He is clearly delighted. A woman walks up to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Fay said to introduce myself.  I'm Lily, Leo's neurotic sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw LILY MARVIN'S picture in Leo's office. Bob stands, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure. I'm neurotic too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, what a coincidence. Am I  disturbing you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only in a good way. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be nice having an analyst in  the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, ask Leo. I'm an analyst  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding?!

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MARVIN'S DARKENED BEDROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Phil empties a large syringe into Marvin's buttock. He sw Marvin's behind and Marvin pulls up his pj's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That should give you some interesting  ideas for your next book. You might  even wake up feeling happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it. Phil, do you remember a  classmate named Fensterwald?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carswell Fensterwald? Sure. Who could  forget?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've forgotten and I don't know why.  Did anything unusual happen with  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I act like a man who's joking?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Leo. I just can't believe  you'd block something like that out.  Carswell was at Harvard with us. You  turned him in for cheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you remember? You brought action  against him for stealing your  psychoanalysis notes and they booted  him. The only place that would take  him after that was University of  Guadalajara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvin tries to speak but nothing comes out of his mouth. Tomsky watches with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, is there something about Carswell  that's disturbing you? Leo...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Phil. Enjoy the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
